title: Caleb A. Skinner - About Me
text:
Hello! I am a second year PhD student in the Department of Statistics at Rice University. I moved to Houston after graduating with my Bachelor’s degree from Baylor University in the Spring 2024.
I’ve always been a curious person, and, for me, statistics is an exciting instrument to uncover relationships and explore unanswered questions in this world. I chose a rigorous PhD program at Rice in order to be equipped to answer these questions. My current research focuses on Bayesian variable/model selection with applications in finance and genomics.


If I’m not modeling or dreaming of statistics, I like to cook with my wife, Sarah, or play a board game with some friends. I love playing and watching tennis (see this website for professional tennis analysis), and on Sunday morning, you’ll find me at my church, Sojourn Montrose. I grew up in Phoenix, Arizona, and I will always agree to a good desert hike.
For more information, check out my GitHub, LinkedIn, and CV.
Please feel free to reach out to me at calebskinner01@gmail.com!

title: Work Experience
text:
Teaching Assistant (2024-2025) - As part of Rice’s PhD program, I serve as a teaching assistant for undergraduate classes. - Courses
Undergraduate Economics Research Assistant (2023)

Researched and developed a data set for Dr. Mark Hoekstra.

Legal Assistant at Gallagher & Kennedy Law Office in Phoenix, AZ (Summer 2021)

Worked directly with Attorneys Shannon Clark and Matt Boatman. Researched dense material for more than 10 personal injury cases. Documented, summarized, and created reports for several depositions, financial documents, and medical records. Communicated with other law firms and businesses to retrieve documents and needed information.

title: Projects
text:
I am interested in a wide variety of statistical topics, but recently I have taken a particular liking to the Bayesian paradigm. Here are a brief list of some projects I have worked on recently. For more projects, please see my GitHub.
Sleeper Bayesian (2024)

With fellow PhD student, Daniel Illera, we model NBA player fantasy performance with a Bayesian normal hierarchical model. We then apply Game Theory principals to develop decision boundaries for fantasy users to optimize their performance.

Skinner, C.; Li, Meng (2025), “Exact Partial Constancy Prior for Structured Ensemble Forecasting” - working paper

Propose a widely applicable exact partial constancy prior for ensembling and forecast aggregation. Paper features specific applications to expert forecasts of unemployment rate and treasury bill rate in the United States.

Skinner, C.; Sturdivant, R. (2024), “Is Momentum Real: On the Existence and Influences of Psychological Momentum in Tennis”

Undergraduate Thesis measuring and analyzing psychological momentum under the direction of Dr. Rodney Sturdivant. You can find the final document here.

SCORE Network Material Developer (Summer 2023)

Researched and compiled formulas, explanations, and examples fit for teaching cluster analysis, inter-rater reliability, and logistic regression. Developed three 20-50-page interactive lesson plans using extensive data from three sports.

Sports Analytics Club – Vice President (2021-2023)

Collaborated with Statistics PhD student Ryan Hebdon to develop a website (with R’s ShinyApp) filled with numerous interactive visualizations and tables utilized by Baylor baseball’s staff.

Global Health Survey (2021-2022)

Produced ~50 pages of visualizations and statistical analysis for a research paper assessing the opinions of Global Health among undergraduate students.

Football Analytics Blitz (2022)

Analyzed NFL data from 2021 to create a comprehensive game-strategy in Syracuse University’s case competition. Produced visualizations justifying decisions and presented conclusions to a panel of judges.
